results.adx_keywords: Classified Information and State Secrets;Archives and Records;Search and Seizure;United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;Justice Department;National Archives and Records Administration;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Trump Organization;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla)
results.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jodi Kantor, Adam Goldman and Ben Protess
results.title: Trump Had More Than 300 Classified Documents at Mar-a-Lago
results.abstract: The National Archives found more than 150 sensitive documents when it got a first batch of material from the former president in January, helping to explain the Justice Department’s urgent response.

media.caption: National Archives officials spent much of 2021 trying to recover material from former President Donald J. Trump that he should have turned over when he left office.
media.copyright: Saul Martinez for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Pets;Veterinary Medicine;Viruses;Dogs;Gaylord (Mich);Michigan
results.byline: By Eduardo Medina and Remy Tumin
results.title: An Unidentified Illness Is Killing Dogs in Michigan, Officials Say
results.abstract: Veterinarians are not sure how contagious the malady is. Most of the dogs affected so far have been under the age of two, an official said.

media.caption: Smokey, a 10-month-old silver Labrador retriever, experienced symptoms that left him lethargic. Officials believe a strain of parvovirus could be to blame for an illness affecting dogs in Michigan.

results.byline: By Kate Golembiewski and François Brunelle
results.title: Your Doppelgänger Is Out There and You Probably Share DNA With Them
results.abstract: That person who looks just like you is not your twin, but if scientists compared your genomes, they might find a lot in common.

media.caption: Charlie Chasen and Michael Malone, Atlanta, 2014.

results.adx_keywords: Postal Service and Post Offices;Dogs;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Pamela Jane Rock;Postal Service (US);Putnam County, Fla.
results.title: Dogs Attack and Kill Mail Carrier in Florida, Officials Say
results.abstract: Pamela Jane Rock had been out delivering mail when her vehicle broke down in Putnam County, Fla. Then, five dogs attacked her, the authorities said.

media.caption: The Putnam County Sheriff’s Office provided this picture of the dogs.

results.title: Woman Opens Fire in Midtown Atlanta, Killing 2 and Injuring 1
results.abstract: A pair of afternoon shootings by the woman, who was later arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, were not random, the police said.

media.caption: The Atlanta Police Department urged people to stay off a number of Midtown streets after the afternoon shootings on Monday.

results.adx_keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Dugina, Daria (1992-2022);Federal Security Service
results.title: The F.S.B. has long faced suspicions that, rather than solving crimes, it stages or hides them.
results.abstract: Like its Soviet-era predecessor, the K.G.B., the F.S.B. has been dogged for years by suspicions that it blames others for crimes it commits itself.

media.caption: In this Sept. 9, 1999 file photo, smoke rises from a Moscow apartment building destroyed by a bomb blast. A notorious series of bombings in the city opened the way for an offensive in Chechnya and for the election of President Putin.

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Archives and Records;Trump, Donald J;Justice Department;Federal Bureau of Investigation;National Archives and Records Administration;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla)
results.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
results.title: Trump, Without the Presidency’s Protections, Struggles for a Strategy
results.abstract: Facing serious legal peril in the documents investigation, the former president has turned to his old playbook of painting himself as persecuted amid legal and political stumbles.

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump is going into battle in the documents investigation without the experienced lawyers who were at his disposal when he was in the White House.
media.copyright: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

results.title: For the first time, a Russian superyacht seized under war-related sanctions will be auctioned.
results.abstract: JP Morgan said that the ship’s owner, Dmitrievich Pumpyansky, a billionaire Russian steel pipe magnate, owed it more than $20 million in loan repayments that could no longer be legally accepted after he was sanctioned by the West.

media.caption: The Axioma superyacht in Gibraltar in March.

results.title: Archbishop Rembert Weakland, Critic of Vatican Orthodoxy, Dies at 95
results.abstract: In his long career, he was an intellectual touchstone for progressive Catholic reformers. But he resigned after the disclosure of a long-ago love affair.

media.caption: Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland in 2009, the year he published a memoir, “A Pilgrim in a Pilgrim Church.” He was archbishop of Milwaukee from 1977 to 2002 but resigned in the wake of a scandal over a love affair in the early 1980s.
